comment: We had this scotch at the same time as we tried Aberlour 12, and it stood out as seeming to be richer, with fuller, darker flavors, and a thicker texture, than that scotch.  That's a pretty big surprise considering that it actually is more diluted.  This is a clear leap above the mediocre Glenfiddich 12.  The nose has some sherry influence as well, and dark, brown sugar aromas.  On the palate, it's a sweet, wine-influenced whisky, but with a buttery sweetness that reminds of a cinnamon roll (albeit with most of the spice brushed off) or a beignet.  The finish is relatively short, with mild, malty flavors.
One of my favorite winter time whiskeys. Plum, fig, and other stone fruit flavors shine with each warming, enjoyable sip.
Smooth and fruity. Plums, figs, and a bit of appricots are present. Viscosityis higher compared to your avergare whiskys. I recommend it on the rocks

This week I'm doing something different. 5 days, 5 whiskies from the same Distillery: Glenfiddich. Starting with the 15 (because for some reason I have in the back of my mind that I didn't like the 12...). This is a fruit bomb. On the nose you are greated with a base layer of honey, topped by a boatload of apples and pears with a dash of cinnamon. This has to be the fruitiest whisky I smelled so far...fresh, juicy apples, you could swear this is apple juice. And this continues on the taste. Honeyed apples with a hint of chocolate and a suggstion of smoke. All in all, light, fruity, moderatly sweet. This is what Speyside stands for in my opinion. The honeyed apples stay quite a while. This is a relax whisky, and a great baseline for my tasting week. Looking forward to the 18 tomorrow. Cheers.
Scent of figs, smoky honey taste with a trace of vanilla
I tried a blind taste test between this and the 12....I could barely tell them apart. Either I got ripped off, my tasting abilities aren't refined enough yet, or this scotch isn't worth it.
God duft, meget let whiskysmag, nedvandet meget, frugtig,
Sweet and fruity with a bit of spice.  Amazing.
Maybe 3.75. Really good and would buy. Similar to 12 year with more caramel and spicier finish
Lots of Leather and spice with a fruitful nose

Nose is great, taste is even better while the finish is both spicy, dry, long and... interesting.
23-23-22-23=91

Rounds up to a 4.0 - nice sweet notes. 

$79.95 in Ontario

Fruity bouquet. Caramel and very slight cinnamon. Smooth with a decent bite. Not very peaty. Raisen dominates the immediate aftertaste but then fades. Not heavy. Finishes warm with a slight linger on the throat. Not much upper lip burn.
Chop. Good not great. Citrus. Water smooths it out. Light yellow.

Nose: honey, oaky, floral with hints of vanilla and some pickle...
Taste: opens up a little tart as flavours of honey and pickle come through finishes with medium alcohol taste and spices. 

*This is the last dram of my bottle which has been exposed to lots of air over the past 2 months.*

During a business trip in Germany last year, the hotelbar had only about a handfull of whiskies to choose from. The only ones I hadn't tried yet, were this one and the Oban 14. While I like the idea of the Solera system, I expected this 15 year old expression of Glenfiddich to be a significant step up from the standard 12 year old, but while it was not bad at all, I also didn't find it to be very special either. A good decent dram, similar to the 12 year old, except for some more fruityness.
Very smooth...not very peaty...has notes of cinnamon
Nice sweet and smooth. Simple and drinkable

really good. smooth and sweet, almost has a bourbon kind of flavor. would definitely drink it again.

tasted at Payne's house.
Definitely affordable and drinkable. Very light on the palate with nice notes of honey figs and moderate spice. 3.5 for me. For the price there are 12 year olds that are better.

- Barris portugueses de ex-sherry
- Barris americanos ex-bourbon
- Barris de carvalho americano virgens finalizam parte dos whiskies envelhecidos em ex-bourbon 
- Método solera, padronização entre lotes

Olfato: leve, cítrico, maçãs, ligeiramente acre, frutado, floral (ao tampar a taça e abrir sente-se com mais facilidade), malte, caramelo, amadeirado, manga verde, uvas passas, mel, baunilha, dulçor, notas de ex-sherry, ex-bourbon e sem indícios de álcool.

Palato: doce do malte, suave, mel, passas, chocolate, baunilha, maçãs, notas de sherry e bourbon evidentes, assim como as notas do barril virgem bem presentes. Picante, um pouco de canela, açúcar mascavo e bom amargor.

Finalização: média para longa, com dulçor, amargor e picância bem balanceados.

Impressões gerais: whisky leve e divisor de águas, caso você venha do mundo dos blends. Leve e ao mesmo tempo complexo e saboroso. Se este whisky tivesse 43% e não fosse filtrado a frio a explosão de sabores seria maior. Entretanto, estamos falando de um ótimo single malt, facilmente encontrado no Brasil, que entrega o que você paga e que tem um preço que não é alto para um whisky de 15 anos. Recomendo degustação em taça de whisky e sem adição de água ou gelo.
Lots of bourbon notes here. Has the spice that I typically like. Lighter on the floral notes than expected. Really good scotch for the classic bourbon lover.

Good, but not a macallan.

Two dollars of each bottle of this is donated to Wounded Warriors, a program that helps soldiers in need. Pouring a brilliant gold with a hint of amber the nose is sweet with aromas of honey and vanilla fudge combined with dark fruits. The palate is full and silky smooth, with layers of marzipan, cinnamon and ginger.

Nose sweet candy
Palette smooth vanilla
Finish leather
One duke
Honey and oak. Noticeably better finish than the 12; no bitter claws at the end
Smooth and friendly easy drinking Scotch that was a gateway for me to the rest of the Scotch world.  Quite nice.
Honey. Light fruit and dark fruit. Apricots and figs. Sherry is there. Not bad.
very good. fruity and sweet. best among 12/15/18 y o glenfiddich
Little bit of a fruity aroma. Taste is very smooth with hints of vanilla. I really like this scotch.
Vanilla, orange and a touch of chocolate. Very easy. An elegant whisky, well worth the price.
Long finish, can definitely taste notes of fruit in it, but little spicy for my preference. Decent whiskey overall.
Simple and light. I was hoping for more complexity

Nose - rum soaked fruit cake

Palate - rich fruity 

Finish - short which i found surprising.

For a 15 yo whilst rich it lacked complexity and the finish was poor compared to other similar aged Whisky’s
Sweet fruit such as fig and raisin on nose, more sweet and the tiniest bit of smoke on palate. Expected more out of a 15 year old, but it is pleasant.

Oak, fruits and spices. Well rounded, nice and safe dram. Nothing special though. Promises more on the nose. My friends like it. 
I rate this Solera somewhere between 3/3.5 out of 5.
Strong bourbon feel but a light burn on the tongue. Smoky, not peaty. Nice
Amazing, complex yet smooth and approachable
Rich and spicy, sweet smoke aftertaste
You can definitely taste the honey and fig in there. Unexpected, but well received!
Somewhat bland. Not peaty, but only mildly malty.

I tasted this in a vertical flight of three Glenfiddichs – this 15 year old along with the familiar green 12 year old and the 18 year old.

While not the worst of the three it was the most disappointing. The nose was mildly interesting, comprised of sherry notes (dark fruits) and red apple.  Similarly, I found the taste to be a little simple: a hot arrival levelling out to a dry, sherry taste, but the sweet and spicy finish was perhaps the highlight. A few drops of water took some bite off the front but didn't open up anything extra, I thought.

Side note: Rather than a Glencairn I used a Túath Irish whiskey glass I got at WhiskeyLive Dublin. It’s a new design that looks well enough and handles fine. It’s main drawback is a flared rim which, despite the marketing blurb, does not “elegantly sit on the surface of the lip”. It requires a significant head-tilt to wet your whistle!
Apples for days. Just a delicious speyside!
Vanilla and dark fruits. Light smoke
Earthy. Light, almost non-existent burn. Heavy tannins. Just flat overall.

Nose: Stone fruit, raisins, cinnamon, hazelnuts
Taste: Honey, vanilla, leather.  Slightly medicinal finish

NOSE: Sweet fresh apple and lemon juice. Honeydew melon. Hints of vanilla.

TASTE: A little green apple. Watery and very soft mouth feel. Pleasant, if not getting a lot of flavor. No spice or smoke.

FINISH: Quite watery but silky smooth. Ends on a pleasant sweet note, albeit short that dries out. You can pick up some oaky bitterness on the tongue.

OVERALL: The nose is great and fresh, and drinks really easy. Simple and enjoyable if you want a light fresh dram.
Smoky and sweet from the bourbon and sherry barrels. This is delicious!
Fruity smell with vanilla undertones. Same taste with a slight medicinal taste to it.
slight hint of oak on nose. spicy flavor with very little peat. finishes clean and spicy. warm throughout. add ice and it sweetens considerably

Nose is unremarkable.

Very smooth, minimal burn. Notes of rum sweetness.
smell: wood. taste: wood. little bit spicey. no peat. neither full nor hollow. closer to light than heavy. nice. not too simple.

Mal schnell hingekritzelt, da Zeitmangel. Sehr fruchtig. Sherry, leicht trockene Noten, beißende Holzaromen, Bourbonfass-Vanille, intensive junge Eiche. Ziemlich lecker und schade, dass der 12 Years dann angeblich deutlich milder ausfällt.

Oaky golden color. Aron fruit and vanilla, very nice. Taste starts fruity and then adds some smoke and oak. There are hints of pepper in the background. Finish is satisfying and smooth. Leaves a bit of peat on the back of the tongue but not overwhelmingly so. A touch of water lets you truly enjoy an almost sweet and savory experience. Nice complexity and a delicious Scotch.
Caramel. complex middle, slight heat at the finish
Back to work tomorrow but enjoying this moment.
Wet stone, baking spice, dark honey, and over ripe pear.

Honey-amber colored. Light bodied and oily.

Nose: fresh lemon and oranges. Subtle cinnamon and clove spices. Notes of milk chocolate, vanilla, and apples round out the aroma with sweetness inviting another pass.

Palate: vanilla sweetness, soft oakiness, cinnamon, lemon juice, a touch of bittersweet cocoa.

Finish: the finish is fairly brief, mildly oaky, and refreshing with milk chocolate and a good dose of citrus from orange and lemons.
One of my favorites.  Strong brown sugar, oak, cream, sherry (but not an overload).  I could sit and smell the empty glass for an hour when done.

This dram has the character of a Speyside whiskey that leans toward the dessert end of the spectrum. Dried fruit and citrus on the nose with honey notes bringing it all together. Super smooth taste that grows in complexity as it sits on the tongue. Perhaps some smoke and leather on the finish. Adding water moves the finish flavors up to be experienced earlier in the taste. A pleasant sip indeed.
not as good as the bourbon barrel 14 year, but still pretty good.

Color: dark gold
Nose: fruity, sweet
Taste: fruity, sweet
Finish: soft, sweet

A pretty good dram for your money!

Simple Nose toffee vanilla however not as sweet tasting as I previously remembered, I got a ripe fruit banana pears flavour with a very oaky spicy hit and a very astringent affect with a complete drying out of the gums leaving a leathery aftertaste and a real bitterness feel with hints of a sort of bitter lemon - this has changed from a few years ago NOT the same whisky for £38 NOT worth a lot better out there for this range

Glenfiddich Solera Reserve 15, Speyside, 92 pts. Elegant, incredibly smooth and easy drinking. Good body, shows some really nice leg. Vanilla/oak, subtle fruit and spice. Approachable and enjoyable, but not a lot of depth.
Good drinking alone or in a scotch and soda. Not as complex as Laphroaig, but smoother and sweeter. Fruit. But also leather.

This has such a mature full bodied scotch. Absolutely nails it on the head. Love the fruitiness and sweetness. Such character and you can really appreciate the uniqueness of using a solera vat for this. It’s a must have in my bar.
Red fruits, christmas cake and ginger. very nice.
Least favourite if the night, too much burn and almost no balance. Red apple jelly belly on the nose and some apple on the palate
This one is my jam! Certainly for the money I will take the 15 over the 18 but I would reserve this for more special occasions.
Great drum, only slightly behind Fiddich 18 for me, but I would probably struggle to recognize one from each other, so great value on this bottle

Colour is deep amber with bronze tones.
Very dark and intense aroma of mellow fruits, even raisins, pear, with nutmeg and vanilla hints, some honey indeed.
The taste is dry with hints of chocolate and raisins - very solid and overwhelming. Apparently much honey - even honey cake, also some marzipan and dark fruits.
Finish is intense, it disappears evenly and lasts long and nice.
A true toughie but a classic one. Deep, hard, intense and very solid. It has everything in moderate - both sweet and dry enough.
Smooth, cinnamon, honey, fruity, and oaky.

The entryway into scotch. A smooth and soft scotch. The Nose is not strong but green apples rule. Palate: hits the tongue watery and smooth. A warm earth and fruit taste, with a spice that greats you as you swallow. Finish, is spicy, and medium length.

Deepen or cook the fruits from Glenfiddich 12 in butter with a little cinnamon. I find this bottle excellent on the nose, but just very good on the palate. Still, I enjoy it and can often find it for a price that lets me just sip and not worry.
Dark colour, almost brown. Very sweet nose which doesn’t really follow through on the taste. Lightly fruit taste  but feels a little flat to start. Very little peat. Good finish.

Nose: raisin, honey, breakfast cereal
Taste: sweet, raisin, cookie
Not super complex but it’s sweet and pleasant. 90

Nose: almost brandied in its sweet, fruity richness. The whisky character is still present but there are elements there that strongly remind me of certain cognacs; prune and dried apricots are the most obvious. Maybe a touch of coconut as well. Very warm and inviting.

Palate: Drier and a little more astringent than the nose would suggest, although still definitely on the sweet side. Lots of dried and candied fruit (orange peel, raisins, dried apricots, maybe dates) under a dusting of warm spices. I can also taste a touch of chocolate. It's got a jovial, Christmas-y feel.

Finish: medium, with strong notes of caramel and a whisper of smoke.

This is not the type of whisky towards which I usually gravitate, but someone gifted it to me and I'm actually glad they did. It's got a satisfying chewiness and a sweet warmth that make it easy to like. I'm almost sure I'll finish the bottle, even though I'm unlikely to repurchase it.
Middle of the road between the 12 and 18. It's a good staple.
So incredibly smooth. I don’t taste the smoke that is supposed to be scant, but the various barrels are very complementary.
Denne var rund i smaken, lett på smak
Fruity and honey nose. Spice on the taste with a oaky spice finish

Nose: Over ripe juicy red apple, and pear, sweetness of a hint of caramel with cinnamon among other spices. 

Taste: The nose is much more sweet and welcoming than the taste. It’s a mouthful of red apple though thin at 40%, some spices, which make it a bit sharp, bitterness on the finish of bakers chocolate with hazelnut.

Gold color, viscous, and looks like chill filtered. Nose is delicate, somewhat weak, with hints of fruit, sherry, honey, and vanilla. Palate is on the sweet side, but not overwhelming, nicely balanced, and has nits of raisins, vanilla, figs, caramel, honey, and oak. Finish is rather short, but interesting, with lemon zest, vanilla, and an oaky-nutty, a bit bitter aftertaste. A few drops of water open even more fruit on the palate, but don’t seem to do too much for this 40% ABV whisky. Overall, this is a very round, smooth, and complex dram that can be greatly enjoyed.
One of my favorites. Smooth and flavorful.
Honestly disappointing. I enjoyed this less than the Glenfiddich 12.
Solid! My go to budget and easy to get scotch.
It is indeed silky smooth. If you can afford it, it's a nice way to introduce people to the world of scotch.

★★★½
On aurait dû ce whisky avant l'autre!
Cette dégustation n'est vraiment pas exceptionnelle. Ce whisky est vraiment mal placé. Il aurait dû être exactement dans mes cordes, mais après le whisky ultra boisé qu'on vient de boire, j'ai l'impression que celui-ci ne goûte rien. C'est tout ce que j'ai à dire.

Typical sweet Scotch smell, with perhaps a bit of smoke lying in wait. Leaving a sip in your mouth brings out the smoke, even infuses it into your taste buds. Swallowing immediately leads to a mellow finish, while opening for air allows an explosion of honeycomb to come to life. Overall a great Scotch balance.
easy to drink, good whisky for casual hangout

Glenfiddich 15 is a well known and easy to find single malt with some rich enjoyable flavors. I think this used to be 43% ABV in the US but unfortunately it looks like it’s 40% now. The color is dark brown and looks too unnatural.

You can find many dried fruits in the nose like raisins and figs. There are also a few nuts and weak spices in the background. 

The palate is sweet and creamy with brown sugar and vanilla. The finish is nice with leather and toffee. 

This is a good step up from the Glenfiddich 12 and a great recommendation for beginners. The flavors are rich, but not complex. While this whisky is enjoyable to drink, it’s not something I’d buy again at this price point.
I get a little vanilla and some smoke. Finishes with vanilla/molasses. Late honey.
Would take the 12 year eight days a week over this one.

Colour: Amber

Nose: Quite fruity. 

Flavour: Fairly sweet. Rounded flavour. The weakest hint of smoke

Finish: Smooth and fairly short.

Another advent calendar review. Very thin, nose is mild and sweet. Fruity and still sweet on the tongue with mild oaky vanilla flavors. For a mild sipper, I prefer it ever so slightly to Dalmore 12, but I'd rather have Balvenie 14 Caribbean Cask.

Nose: pear, butter, toffee, caramel, roses, floral tea, hibiscus, orange 

Palate: caramel, rose hip, oak, butter, shortbread, very woody, apple 

Finish: rose hip, oak, slight toffee
Sweet smell and aftertaste. Strong bite. Slightly smokey on the palette, dissipates quickly.
Soft burn. Sherry comes through right away. Light fruit aftertaste. Bit of toasted Caramel. Still on my tongue as I type this out.
Smells sherry and candied fruit. Tastes of candied fruitcake.  2018/2019 advent- 8

Rich and full of characters I get fruit and honey before a smooth smoke finish.

Super smooth.  One of my favorites to just sit and sip neat.  Good, mellow flavors.

Ex bourbon notes are covered with delicious sherry dry fruit notes. Floral notes is just floating in and out in between. Everything is just light not heavy.

American oak wood, charred, bitterness started to show on your palate a lot more intensely and vividly where it was hidden away on the nose. All the goodness of bourbon sugary notes and wonderful dry fruit sherry notes all started to fade away from foreground to background until you left with a bit dry and a bit bitterness almost like a black tea even and some spicy notes in your month.

Once you had couple of sip, sherry notes and American oak will be more prominent on the nose.

There is too much American oak notes in there for me to love it. I like it but I don't love it.
Very silky and smooth. Great finish, not harsh.
Very unexpected in a good way. Smooth and fruity with a sherry finish.
delicious, good taste that doesn't last long

Nose: Strong Apple
Palate: Fruits and wood
Finish: Mild spice that lingers
Nose of vanilla and apple. Sweet, creamy vanilla and orange. Apple on the taste as well. Very well balanced. Finish is smooth and short. Good, easy drinking whiskey.
Day 1 of Advent calendar! Fruity and sweet nose--apples, honey, vanilla. Full, rich body,  with a smooth heat aftertaste. Very nice.
Best out of the mainstream glenfiddich line. Tastes a little medicinal
It’s fine - vanilla, chocolate, raisins, classic sherry flavors, but very light and lacks any kind of concentration of flavor.  Disappointing for the price.
Any Glen will do! Jokes aside this was super nice. Maybe too nice, smooth and sweet, full of candy and Carmel notes.

Nose: A fruit bomb, citrus, red fruits, apple, even melon, honey, lightly toasted bread, 

Taste:   Sweet and juicy. With warm cider, honey, with a slightly breaded finish. 

Experience:  Early summer, the sun is warm but not hot and everything is ripe and juicy, taking a big bite of your favorite fruit it drips off the sides of your mouth, you don't care though because ti tastes so good.
I really enjoy this Glenfiddich scotch. It will always be a reliable choice.
Neat with a few drops of water. Let it warm and the nose is the most amazing butterscotch. Taste is unami, berries, and oak with a nice sherry heat. Finish is all about oaky sherry.
not bad, but some disturbing taste

Classic whisky with a touch of honey and a whole floral taste.
Perfect example of a balance whisky with a floral ending
Nose of apples, taste is sweet with a little spice at the end.
Muy buen whisky dulce poco ahumado aprecio algo de cerezas, cuero un final largo es rico
Not much on the nose but it tastes like god water. Vanilla and caramel tap dance on your tongue and leave you with a warm mouth feel.
Nariz con tostados, cereal, miel y toffe, especiados muy presentes. Boca amplia, te hace salivar mucho. Muy buen volumen. Muy disfrutable por ese precio
Strong wheat and floral notes on the nose. Surprisingly very smooth. Slightly sweet and oily with heavy wheat notes. Not much fire in the mouth or the belly. Very mild and slightly bitter aftertaste.
Enjoying this quite a bit today.  Vanilla, oak, sugary cereal, a little floral honey.
Another solid scotch finished in sherry casks... I’m starting to see a pattern...

Nose: fruity with some earthy-ness to it
Taste: malted sweetness, tastes delicious, a hint of smoke but overall very smooth
4.25. Very pleasant and smooth. Fruit on nose with a scant amount of peat. Fruity on tongue, slight pepper. Very nice all around.

This is my first single malt since i've actually learned how to drink whisky and know how to nose it and taste it properly. I have made reviews only for blends and one single grain. This whisky is very good, on the nose you get a little herbal like mint notes, honey, but most of it is caramel or vanilla. You will the get the impression it is going to be sweet but actually the sweetness is only for a second in your palate. After that second, you will get a full bodied peppery sensation, very strong which will leave your mouth hot and dry. actually it is a beautiful drink, i've enjoyed it a lot.  89 over 100

On the heels on my review of the 12 year, I think now is a good time to tackle its older brother. The 15-year Solera. On an interesting concept; as a result a good portion of this juice is well older than 15 years old. Ex-bourbon, ex-sherry, virgin oak. Let's check it out.

Nose: Heavy vanilla, caramel, and orange citrus. Honey, toffee, ginger, and oak. Classic Fiddich apple, pear, and apricot, kiwi, and floral notes. Graham cracker and walnut. Some golden raisin and white grape, but otherwise, not a huge sherry presence. Maybe a bit of cranberry. The Bourbon cask definitely exerts the most prominent influence on the nose. I read French Toast on the internet. Not my note, but it it's undeniable that's there. Good start.

Palate: It's a fruit bowl. Apple, pear, orange, plum, apricot, golden raisin, fig, date, cranberry, white and red grape. A lot going on there. A bit of cola and some chewy caramel. I'm getting some those raspberry-flavored Valentine's chocolates (don't even know what else to call it). Big toffee, big malt, plenty of vanilla and oak. The sherry and bourbon oak share the load this time around. I've got little experience with Virgin Oak, so I'm going to leave that out of my analysis. Good stuff.

Finish: Some dark fruit (cranberry, date, fig, raisin), coupled with vanilla and toffee. More of the apple, pear, and kiwi. A bit of a cinnamon and oak kick. It's somewhere between short and moderate length, leaning toward the latter. Not all that long, but there's plenty of complexity while it lasts.

Another 4 star outing for Glenfiddich. To me, they offer a very consistent product. But as long as they're bottling at 40%, they'll never crack the threshold that divides very good and great. The 14 remains the best of the age-stated GFs I've tried, and, no coincidence, it's bottled at 43%. Honestly, I think all of these could use a 3% bump to really achieve their potential.

While they cut corners on the proof here, they certainly did not hold back on the aged-stock. The Solera aging method works wonders here. It's a refined yet flavorful expression; I think the interplay between multiple generations of malt makes for a fantastic product. Great job here Glendfiddich; I doubt you'll ever increase the ABV on  your products because, ultimately, the bottom line rules. So I've heard. At any rate, thanks for a solid bottle.

Apple juice and raisins.  The unique Solera maturation produces a very smooth, balanced, and easy sipping sherry-cask scotch.  I will always keep a bottle of this on my shelf, because it reminds me of what I was looking for in an ideal sherried whisky when I first started my scotch exploration.  There's none of the sulfur elements or heavy wood presence, to detract my attention away from the simplicity of everything I enjoy in a daily, sherried dram.

Rating Glossary:  

Two Stars:           "I'd rather be drinking lite beer."
Two 1/2 Stars:    "Posh rubbish."
Three Stars:        "I love whisk(e)y.  This is average love."
Three 1/2 Stars: "May buy again."
Four Stars:          "I've got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better." got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better."
Bloemig, hint gember. Hout, beetje turf. Vol, kruidig.
Very sweet nose with rich caramel. Herbal. Rich taste, palette develops from sweet, a little spicy, and then ash. Clean finish. Very nice!
Cherry, Citrus, Dark Chocolate, Red Apple.
Sweet floral nose feels slightly artificial. Sweet taste. Very sweet and pleasant. Slightly Smokey and slightly bitter finish.

Nose is warm and inviting, with malt and caramel, followed by sweet dates and figs. It’s so gentle you wouldn’t even assume it has any alcohol in it.

At first taste it reminds you that indeed it is a scotch, with that undeniable Speycide smoke, but not heavy, in fact only at the front of the palate. By midway it’s retreated to more malt and honey and citrus.

The finish is friendly and smooth, not overly sweet nor overly warm. 

Overall this is a very enjoyable whisk(e)y that anyone would be pleased to have poured for them. Would purchase again.

Lite, elegant, soft, spicy, warming but not enough on a winter evening.  Easy drinking with a more brisk feeling taste that doesn’t linger.  Cinnamon, green apples, caramel?, brown sugar? Delightful in the morning!😉
Very smooth and velvety. No peat flavor

Nose: Almost doesn’t even smell like Scotch. Very sweet with a little smoke. Fruity and spicy. Vanilla present as well giving it a syrupy smell.

Palate: As sweet as the nose. The casks smokiness is strong and blends well alongside the sweetness. Vanilla notes keep it smooth.

Finish: Medium-long. Smokiness lingers and keeps it interesting. Oaky and sweet.

Overall Thoughts: This is a delightful dram. Glenfiddich rarely disappoints me and the 15 certainly holds that to be true. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a Scotch that doesn’t try too hard to be bold. It’s a sweet one that is easy to relax with.
Sweet and fruity tones as soon as it hits your nose. Notes of honey and vanilla and very distinguishable on the palate, with a very smooth finish.

Almost no smell very light smell of honey. Wonderful smoke honey taste that is slowly followed by a very light vanilla. Has a great after taste of dry fruit that lingers just for the perfect amount of time.
Nose is a bit indistinct for me, spirit and some feint orange. Palate is more butterscotch, honey and typical Speyside fruit cake. Finish medium long with a slight bitter chocolate tinge.
